raw_text:
Cebit opens to mobile music tune
 
 Cebit, the world's largest hi-tech fair, has opened its doors in Hanover for a look at the latest technologies for homes and businesses.
 
 There are more than 6,000 exhibitors registered and about 500,000 visitors are expected to pass through the doors. Third generation mobiles, the digital home and broadband are key themes at the show. Camera phones will get better resolutions as vendors set out to prove that bigger is definitely better. Samsung is set to steal some initial limelight with the launch of a 7-megapixel phone on the opening day.
 
 The SCH-V770 has some of the features of high-end digital single lens reflex cameras such as manual focus and the ability to attach a telephoto or wide-angle lens. Camera phones are likely to prove an interesting battle ground at the show, said Ben Wood, principal analyst at research firm Gartner. "It is firmly established that cameras are an integral part of phones and now the technology arms race is on in terms of megapixels. There will be a certain amount of 'look how big mine is'," he said. There will also be increasing focus on music-enabled mobiles. "At 3GSM in Cannes everyone went music mad and music is going to be a big theme for all the vendors at Cebit," said Mr Wood. Sony Ericsson will use the fair to show off the W800 - its recently unveiled Walkman branded phone - and there is speculation that Motorola may unveil its ROKR handset, widely tipped as the first to carry Apple's iTunes music software. Apple and Motorola announced they were getting together at the end of last year as a result of a long-standing friendship between Motorola's chief executive Ed Zander and Steve Jobs.
 
 Some analysts think Motorola may save the launch for CTIA, a wireless show in America the following week, which could be a telling sign about how operators are coming to view the German tech fair.
 
 "One of the interesting things is that CeBIT is clearly a show in decline," said Mr Wood. "A lot of the big players, such as Nokia, are pulling back saying it is hard to justify a big presence at all of the shows. It could be the last big year for Cebit," he said. Other themes include TV-enabled mobiles which are bound to create a buzz in the halls as Vodafone unveils a prototype handset that can show live digital television. There has been a glut of recent headlines about mobile TV - French operators are teaming up, O2 is trialling a system in Oxford, UK, and Nokia begins trialling a system in Finland with the Finnish Broadcasting Company, YLE TV and commercial TV channels. Cebit could become the battleground for the two competing methods for getting TV on to mobiles, and is also likely to provide a stage for a technology slated to compete with 3G. HSDPA (High Speed Downlink Packet Access) has been described as "3G on steroids" and could offer consumers much faster download times. For instance, a song which currently takes one and a half minutes to download to a phone could be done in 10 seconds. Korean giants LG Electronics and Samsung will show off HSDPA handsets at the show and the technology is set to be rolled out in the US, Europe and Korea next year. Broadband will continue to be a key theme at the show with internet telephony proving this year's killer application.
 
 Germany's largest online service provider, T-Online, is tipped to reveal software for low-cost net telephony which would see it competing with its parent company Deutsche Telekom. Cebit is used by many to unveil cutting edge products and in the mobile sphere this is likely to mean a lot of bright, colourful handsets as fashion continues to compete with technology when it comes to the device everyone has in their pockets. Rainbow-coloured phones, influenced by handsets from Japan, are just one example of how Asian companies will stamp their mark on this year's show, at which they will have their biggest ever presence. Cebit organisers have created a digital home in Hall 25 of the 27 hangar-like buildings that will house the show. "The digital home will be a hyped theme at the show. The house will be totally wired and full of things that can be used for home entertainment," said Cebit organiser Gabriele Dorries.
llama3.2:1b:
Cebit, the world's largest hi-tech fair, has opened in Hanover with over 6,000 exhibitors and 500,000 visitors expected.

The show features themes such as digital single lens reflex cameras, high-end mobiles, music-enabled mobiles, TV-enabled mobiles, broadband technology, HSDPA handsets, internet telephony software, low-cost net telephony, and fashion-inspired mobile devices.

Samsung is set to launch a 7-megapixel phone on opening day. Motorola may unveil its ROKR handset, and Apple and Motorola are planning to partner at the end of last year.

Other exhibitors include Nokia, Sony Ericsson, LG Electronics, and Vodafone, which will showcase various products in their respective areas.

Cebit is expected to be a show in decline as big players like Nokia pull back. However, it may still have one or two major events left before it closes.
llama3.2:3b: Cebit, the world's largest hi-tech fair, has opened in Hanover with over 6,000 exhibitors registered and 500,000 visitors expected. Key themes include third-generation mobiles, digital homes, broadband, camera phones with high megapixel resolutions, music-enabled mobiles, and TV-enabled handsets with live digital television capabilities. HSDPA technology will also be showcased, offering faster download times. Analysts predict Motorola may unveil its iTunes-compatible ROKR handset, while Asian companies are expected to make a big impact on the show's fashion aspect, including rainbow-coloured phones.
gemma2:2b: Cebit, the world's largest hi-tech fair, has opened in Hanover. 6000 exhibitors are presenting latest technologies for homes and businesses. Key themes include: third generation mobiles with increased camera resolutions; digital homes and broadband; music-enabled phones; and HSDPA (High Speed Downlink Packet Access), a faster download technology.  Sony Ericsson will showcase the W800 Walkman phone, while Motorola may unveil its ROKR handset. Analysts think mobile TV will be a hot topic at Cebit. Vendors are also showing off their low-cost net telephony software. Finally, fashion will continue to play a role in the design of new phones with Asian companies having a large presence this year.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Cebit's annual technology fair is set to showcase new devices such as high-resolution cameras, smartphone upgrades, music-enabled mobiles, TV-enabled phones, and internet telephony technologies. The event has attracted over 6,000 exhibitors and 500,000 visitors, with many expecting about 7 megapixels in camera phones. Some analysts predict that Cebit may not have a big presence at CTIA this year.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Cebit, Europe's largest tech fair, showcases third-generation mobiles, digital homes, broadband, camera phones with higher pixel counts, music-enabled phones, TV-compatible devices, and HSDPA technology, predicting its decline as Nokia pulls back from participating in the shows due to high costs.
qwen2.5:3b: Cebit, the world's largest tech fair in Hanover, features over 6,000 exhibitors and expects around 500,000 visitors. Key themes include third-generation mobiles, digital homes, broadband, camera phones with better resolutions, music-enabled devices, TV on mobiles (like Vodafone’s prototype), and HSDPA technology for faster downloads. Analysts predict Cebit may be a turning point as major players like Nokia reduce their presence. The fair also highlights the growing trend of a 'digital home' integrating various entertainment options. Asian companies will have their largest-ever representation, influencing trends like rainbow-colored phones.

deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Okay, so I need to summarize this text about Cebit's Hanover fair. Let me read through it carefully first.

The text starts by mentioning that Cebit is opening its doors in Hanover to showcase the latest technologies for homes and businesses. They've got over 6,000 exhibitors and expect around 500,000 visitors. Third generation mobiles, digital home, and broadband are key themes.

It talks about camera phones getting better resolutions as vendors aim to prove bigger is better. Samsung is set to launch a 7-megapixel phone on opening day, which should catch attention because they're big in the industry.

Gartner principal analyst Ben Wood mentions that cameras are an integral part of phones and that the technology arms race among megapixels will be intense. There might be a 'look how big mine is' meme happening at the show.

He also points out that music-enabled mobiles, especially 3GSM in Cannes where people were music-happy there, will be another major theme. Sony Ericsson will showcase their Walkman phone brand, and while Motorola is mentioned to be working with Apple for their ROKR handset, some analysts are concerned about the launch timing.

Others highlight that CeBIT's decline might mean big companies like Nokia and others are pulling back, possibly due to the show being in a bad year. TV-enabled mobiles will create buzz as Vodafone partners with O2 on a live digital TV system, and others like LG, Samsung, and HSDPA products will be introduced.

T-Online is expected to launch low-cost net telephony software, competing with Deutsche Telekom. Asian companies are expected to dominate this year's show, with phones using Japanese tech influencing their presence. Cebit's digital home theme in Hall 25 of the hangar is meant to showcase cutting-edge products for consumers.

I need to condense all this into a concise summary that includes key points without too much detail. I'll make sure to mention the main themes like camera phones, megapixel phones, 3G and music, TV, HSDPA, online services, and how Cebit is setting up its digital home with Asian companies.

Let me structure it so each major theme is highlighted clearly. Make sure to include Ben Wood's comments about the technology arms race and cameras being an integral part of phones.
</think>

Cebit is set to open its Hanover fair showcasing the latest mobile tech, including camera phones that improve resolution and 3G-enabled mobiles with music as a trend. Key themes are camera phones, megapixel phones, 3G and music, TV-enabled mobiles, HSDPA products, online services like internet telephony, and an immersive digital home theme at Hall 25. Analyst Ben Wood notes the competition between megapixels in the technology arms race and concerns about CebIT's show timing, potentially causing big companies to pivot, while T-Online will launch low-cost net telephony software against competitors.
tinyllama:1.1b: Cebit has opened its doors for the mobile music tune, third-generation mobile phones, and broadband, with more than 6,000 exhibitors registered and about 500,000 visitors expected to pass through the doors. Third-generation mobile phones are set to steal some initial limelight as vendors set out to prove that bigger is better. Camera phone brand Samsung will unveil its own digital single lens reflex (DSLR) camera phone, while Sony Ericsson will show off its Walkman branded handset, which has been widely tipped for the first-to-carry Apple's iTuins music software at CeBIT. In recent years, the mobile tech fair has seen a decline in attendance and a flurry of big players pulling back as operators come to view the German show as "hard to justify". Other themes include TV-enabled mobile phones, which could lead to a battleground for competing methods for getting TV on mobiles. Cebit will stage CeBIT's first digital home and is set to have a major presence in Hall 25 of the four halls hosting the show.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The 2010 edition of Cebit, held in Hanover, Germany, has opened its doors to the public with the aim of providing a platform for innovation and showcasing cutting-edge technologies for homes and businesses. The event is set to draw over 500,000 visitors from around the world, providing an excellent opportunity for companies in the hi-tech industry to demonstrate their latest products and services.
phi:2.7b: Cebit, the world's largest hi-tech fair, is set to showcase the latest technologies for homes and businesses. More than 6,000 exhibitors are registered, with an expected attendance of 500,000 visitors. Third-generation mobile technology, digital home solutions, and broadband connectivity are key themes at the show. Camera phones are being positioned as a battleground, with increased focus on music-enabled mobiles. Sony Ericsson plans to unveil its W800, which is based on the Walkman brand. The launch of Motorola' ROKR phone may also be revealed at Cebit, and industry analysts believe that Motorola may save it for CTIA in America, where operators are becoming increasingly skeptical about the value of attending the German tech fair. Some analysts predict that this could mark a decline in the show's popularity. Other themes include TV-enabled mobiles, which are bound to create buzz as Vodafone unveils a prototype handset capable of displaying live digital television. The show also has the potential to showcase HSDPA technology, dubbed "3G on steroids," which will offer faster download speeds for consumers. LG Electronics and Samsung will exhibit their versions of HSDPA handsets at Cebit. Internet telephony is another key theme this year, with T-Online set to reveal software that could offer low-cost net telephony services to customers. The show also promises to showcase a variety of colorful and trendy mobile phones influenced by Japanese devices. Germany's largest online service provider, T-Online, may announce its HSDPA technology at Cebit.

granite3.1-dense:2b:
Cebit, Europe's premier tech fair in Hanover, has officially opened with over 6,000 exhibitors and anticipated 500,000 visitors. Key themes include third-generation mobiles, digital homes, broadband, camera phones, and music-enabled devices.

Samsung will debut a 7-megapixel phone on the opening day, marking an intense competition for larger megapixel counts among manufacturers. The W800, a Walkman-branded Sony Ericsson handset, and possibly Motorola's ROKR, expected to support Apple's iTunes music software, will also be showcased due to their partnership announced last year.

Analysts predict that Cebit may be the final major event for big tech companies like Nokia, signaling a potential decline of the fair. However, themes such as TV-enabled mobiles and HSDPA (3G on steroids) will dominate, with live digital television and significantly faster downloads (down to 10 seconds from 1.5 minutes) promised by LG Electronics and Samsung.

Broadband remains a focus, with T-Online planning to unveil low-cost internet telephony software for competition against Deutsche Telekom. The digital home theme in Hall 25 will feature fully wired entertainment systems influenced by Asian designs.
